details.name: Biomarkers for CTCs
details.description: DNA methylation profiles of circulating tumor cells (CTCs) in colorectal cancer.
details.findings: The study identified specific DNA methylation patterns that distinguish CTCs from primary tumors and normal blood cells. These biomarkers could be used for early detection, monitoring disease progression, and guiding treatment decisions.
details.notes: Data is publicly available at the Gene Expression Omnibus (GEO) repository with the Accession Number GSE220096.

details.name: glycoprotein NMR signals
details.description: Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) signals from glycosylated acute phase proteins in human serum.
details.findings: NMR can identify a range of glycosylated acute phase proteins from one single measurement, providing information on glycan structures. This method is non-destructive and not dependent on the type of glycosylation.
details.notes: NMR has an advantage over nephelometry in that it specifically observes glycosylated acute phase proteins and is not affected by variations in glycan structures.

details.name: glycan structures

details.name: nephelometry
details.description: A diagnostic method used to measure the concentration of proteins in a sample by detecting light scattering.
details.findings: Nephelometric methods are sensitive to glycosylation and may yield erroneous results when glycan structures interfere with antibody binding. NMR, on the other hand, is not affected by these limitations.
details.notes: Nephelometry is currently the diagnostic gold-standard for measuring acute phase proteins but has limitations in detecting variations in glycan structures.

details.name: RAS

details.name: BRAF V600E

details.name: hCRISPRs
details.description: Human CRISPR RNAs (hCRISPRs) are short RNA molecules that can be detected in human samples.
details.findings: hCRISPRs were identified and validated as potential biomarkers for transcriptional activity. They were detected using various technologies including RT-qPCR, SHERLOCK, and DETECTR.
details.notes: hCRISPRs are related to CRISPR-Cas systems and can be used for diagnostic purposes.

details.name: acetone
details.description: A chemical compound with a fruity odor that can be present in exhaled breath.
details.findings: Acetone concentration changes during activities such as exercising or fasting, making it less reliable as a biomarker. It is also influenced by exogenous factors like physical activity and smoking.
details.notes: While acetone has been considered for use as a cancer biomarker, its reliability is affected by various external factors.

details.name: 4-heptanone
details.description: A chemical compound that has been detected in exhaled breath.
details.findings: The origin of 4-heptanone is unclear, and it is not recommended for use as a biomarker due to this uncertainty.
details.notes: Further research on the origins of 4-heptanone is needed to determine its potential as a biomarker.

details.name: acetone (as a cancer biomarker)
details.description: A chemical compound with a fruity odor that has been considered for use as a cancer biomarker.
details.findings: Acetone cannot itself represent an appropriate biomarker due to changes in concentration during activities like exercising or fasting.
details.notes: While acetone is of interest, its reliability as a biomarker is limited by external factors.

details.name: Microbiome composition
details.description: The overall composition of bacteria in the gut microbiome.

SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP) values were used to identify key bacterial taxa that contribute to the discrimination between CRC patients and healthy controls.
details.notes: The study highlights the importance of specific bacterial taxa in distinguishing CRC cases from healthy individuals.

details.findings: The article mentions that Fusobacterium nucleatum is significantly enriched in CRC patients compared to healthy controls, as identified through SHAP values.
details.notes: Fusobacterium nucleatum has been previously linked to CRC in other studies.

details.name: Acetone
details.description: A ketone and a secondary product of lipid peroxidation. It is a good predictor for ketosis and forms under metabolic conditions associated with a high oxidation rate of fatty acids.
details.findings: Acetone was found to be elevated in the exhaled breath of CRC patients compared to controls, suggesting it may be a biomarker for oxidative stress or altered metabolism in cancer.

details.name: Alcohols
details.description: Originates from food and alcohol beverages, as well as the metabolism of hydrocarbons by cytochrome p450 enzymes.
details.findings: The levels of alcohols were not explicitly mentioned in the article, but they are part of the VOCs that can be detected in exhaled breath and may vary in CRC patients due to different metabolic processes.

details.name: Hydrocarbons
details.description: Emission is affected by oxidative stress, which is the balance between formation and scavenging of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and free radicals in the body. Unmetabolized hydrocarbons are excreted in the breath due to their low solubility in blood.
details.findings: Hydrocarbons were found to be part of the VOCs detected in exhaled breath, and their levels may vary in CRC patients due to oxidative stress.

details.name: Esters

details.name: T-antigen

[BEGIN ARTICLE]:<content></content>
[END ARTICLE]

[INSTRUCTIONS]
Generate list of biomarkers that are topic of the article and for each such biomarker extract name, description, type, findings explicitly mentioned in the article, list of knowledge that consist of 'predicate' about the finding from findings and 'object' which biomarker is subject and related via 'predicate'.
Return the response in strict JSON format with the following structure:

[
  { "name": "biomarker name","type":"biomarker type","description":"biomarker description","findings":"findings about biomarker in article","notes":"additional notes important to biomarker", "knowledge":[{'predicate':'some predicate from findings of biomarker','object':'object that relates via predicate to the biomarker' }],
  { "name": "biomarker2 name","type":"biomarker2 type","description":"biomarker2 description","findings":"findings about biomarker2 in article","notes":"additional notes important to biomarker2", "knowledge":[{'predicate':'some predicate from findings of  biomarker2','object':'object that relates via predicate to the biomarker2' }] }
] 

Ensure there is no additional explanation, only return valid JSON.
